explanation: The agent's argument is not persuasive: the early-return (if (0 == length) return;) is not provably dead code under MISRA Rule 2.2. Removal of that return would cause additional instructions to execute (computations of bytes_have, updates/reads of ctx->count, possible branch and loop tests, additional memory reads, etc.). MISRA Note 1 explicitly treats timing and the time at which actions occur as part of program behaviour for embedded systems — changing the amount of work performed (and thus timing, memory accesses, stack usage, etc.) can therefore change observable behaviour. There are also plausible side-effects (memory writes/reads, register usage, cache effects, interaction with concurrency or debugging instrumentation) even if the arithmetic results are unchanged for length == 0. Because removal can affect behaviour in these ways, the early-return cannot be classified as dead code per Rule 2.2, so the reported violation is not correct.
